title: Change in momentum from force-time equation

content.question: The net force <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> acting on an object that moves along a straight line is given as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by <math alttext="F of t equals kappa t squared plus tau" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>κ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="kappa equals 1 newton per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>κ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext> N/</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="tau equals 1 newton" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the change in momentum of the object from <math alttext="t equals 0 second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="6 kilogram meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="10 kilogram meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="12 kilogram meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="30 kilogram meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
It cannot be determined without knowing the initial momentum of the object.

content.answer: <math alttext="12 kilogram meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
